choices.A: It succeeds and displays all the tablespaces that belong to the root database.
choices.C: It succeeds and displays all the tablespaces that belong to the root and pluggable databases.
choices.B: It fails and returns an error because a connection is not made by using the sysdba privilege.
choices.D: It fails and returns an error because SQL commands cannot be executed at the RMAN prompt.

discussion.content:
Answer:BC
The value for TBS_PERCENT_USED specifies the percentage of the tablespace quota when a tablespaceis considered full. The value for TBS_PERCENT_FREE specifies the targeted free percentage for thetablespace. When the percentage of the tablespace quota reaches the value of TBS_PERCENT_USED,ADO begins to move data so that percent free of the tablespace quota approaches the value ofTBS_PERCENT_FREE. This action by ADO is a best effort and not a guarantee.
i dont agree with Option B ,since if the tablespace is made read only,there is no chance to alter,update,delete objects in that tablespace..

choices.C: The movement of some segments to a target tablespace with a higher degree of compression, on a different storage tier, when the source tablespace exceeds T3S percent used
choices.D: Taking the target tablespace offline after the segments are moved
choices.A: The movement of all segments to a target tablespace with a higher degree of compression, on a different storage tier, when the source tablespace exceeds tbs percent used
choices.B: Setting the target tablespace to read-only after the segments are moved
choices.E: The movement of some blocks to a target tablespace with a lower degree of compression, on a different storage tier, when the source tablespace exceeds tbs percent used

questions.question_text:
In your database, the tbs percent used parameter is set to 60 and the tbs percent free parameter is set to 20.
Which two storage-tiering actions might be automated when using Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) to automate data movement?

comments.content: Yes, but when you are connected to the root you are able to specify the default temporary tablespace (which is in the root container) which will be the default for the pdb's which have not specified a temporary tablespace of their own.

discussion.content:
A and C are correct.

B is false. You can execute:
CONN pdb_admin@pdb1
ALTER DATABASE DEFAULT TEMPORARY TABLESPACE temp;

choices.E: The amount of space that each PDB can use in a shared temporary tablespace must be set at the CDB level.
choices.B: The current container must be set to root to create or modify the default temporary tablespace or tablespace group for a CDB.
choices.C: Each PDB can have its own default temporary tablespace.
choices.A: Default permanent tablespaces can be shared across pluggable databases (PDBs).
choices.D: The default permanent tablespace for a PDB can be changed only by a local user with the required permissions.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about tablespaces in multitenant container databases (CDBs)?
Which two options can be configured for an existing database by using the Database Configuration Assistant (DBCA)?

questions.question_text: You have set the value of the NLS_TIMESTAMP_TZ_FORMAT parameter to YYYY-MM-DD. The default format of which two data types would be affected by this setting?

discussion.content: The NLS_TIMESTAMP_TZ_FORMAT parameter defines the default date format for the TIMESTAMP and TIMESTAMP WITH LOCAL TIME ZONE datatypes.
